H0.text: Electrons are the tiny particles that make up a constant stream of electricity.

H1.text: Atoms are the tiny particles that constitute a constant stream of electricity.

H2.text: Quarks are the tiny particles that electricity consists of a constant stream of.

H3.text: Ions are the tiny particles that constitute a constant stream in electricity.

A4.text: When free electrons – both in vacuum and metals – move, they produce a net flow of charge called an electric current, which generates a magnetic field.

A5.text: In metals, the outermost electrons are delocalised and able to move freely, accounting for the high electrical and thermal conductivity of metals.
